a well functioning legal aid system can streamline the proceedings it can reduce the time suspects are kept in detention they can limit the number of wrongful convictions they can reduce prison overcrowding and congestion in court
some of the benefits are extremely difficult to measure in monetary terms and here am talking primarily about the benefits due to avoid detention and reduced number of wrongful convictions

amendment thirty nine aims to restrict the possibility for member states to recover legal aid costs and this restriction would be limited to two conditions the first one is that the final decision establishing

that person does not meet the eligibility criteria for ordinary legal aid would have to be taken and the second condition is if falls information on personal financial situation would be provided by the suspect so in these two situations member states would be able to recover legal aid costs

amendment forty two bears with european arrest warrant it sets an obligation on the issuing member state to ensure that provisional and ordinary legal aid is provided in the issuing state moreover it sets an obligation on a third member state where evidence gathering takes place to provide legal aid

the provision of legal aid in the issuing state would ensure the effectiveness of the right to dual representation in both the executing and issuing state according to the directive on access to a lawyer collaboration between lawyers in the issuing and executing states would result in fewer in appropriate or iraniasewrequests

legal aid in the issuing state would also increase the chances of finding alternative solutions in some cases so this might lead to withdrawal of warrants these alternative solutions these are for example video conferences used for hearings instead of direct hearings

the benefits would be due to avoidance of costly proceedings in cases of wrongful surrender and we could also expect reduction of the significant human costs related to deprivation of liberty and wrongful convictions total costs of this amendment have been estimated in the range of zero six one three million annually
